qas.question: What Köppen climate classification does Plymouth possess?
In degrees Fahrenheit, what is Plymouth's annual mean temperature?
What month in Plymouth has the lowest temperatures?
Up to how many centimeters of snow fell on Plymouth between 17 and 19 December 2010?
Along with August, what is typically the hottest month in Plymouth?

context: Along with the rest of South West England, Plymouth has a <a0_0>temperate oceanic<a0_0/> climate (Köppen Cfb) which is generally wetter and milder than the rest of England. This means a wide range of exotic plants can be grown. The annual mean temperature is approximately 11 °C (<a1_0>52<a1_0/> °F). Due to the modifying effect of the sea the seasonal range is less than in most other parts of the UK. As a result of this summer highs are lower than its southerly latitude should warrant, but as a contrast the coldest month of <a2_0>February<a2_0/> has mean minimum temperatures as mild as between 3 and 4 °C (37 and 39 °F). Snow is rare, not usually equating to more than a few flakes, but there have been exclusions, namely the European winter storms of <a3_0>20<a3_0/>09-10 which, in early January, covered Plymouth in at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) of snow; more on higher ground. Another period of notable snow occurred from 17–19 December 2010 when up to 8 inches (20 cm) of snow fell through the period – though only 2 inches (5.1 cm) would lie at any one time due to melt. Over the 1961–1990 period, annual snowfall accumulation averaged less than 7 cm (3 in) per year. <a4_0>July<a4_0/> and August are the warmest months with mean daily maxima over 19 °C (66 °F).
